title: Information associated with commitment to plant & main 300 WW1 memorial trees 'in perpetuity'.

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Freedom of Information request - Information associated with commitment to plant & main 300 WW1 memorial trees 'in perpetuity'.
On Wednesday the 13th of December 2017, Sheffield City Council (SCC) held a Cabinet meeting and resolved a number of points. Quote:
“c)
APPROVES 300 NEW MEMORIAL TREES TO BE PLANTED IN SHEFFIELD’S PARKS BY THE COUNCIL BEFORE NOVEMBER 2018 to create a permanent lasting war memorial for the city;
(e)
GUARANTEES THAT THE 300 NEW TREES IN PARKS AND ANY POSSIBLE REPLACEMENT TREES ON THE WAR MEMORIAL STREETS, BE REPLANTED IN PERPETUITY.”
SOURCE:
https://democracy.sheffield.gov.uk/docum...
https://web.archive.org/web/202012082128...
On Wednesday the 25th of April 2018, SHEFFIELD TELEGRAPH reported the following:
“Living tributes to the city's war dead are to be planted by the council at 36 sites - including all of Sheffield's major city and district parks - with the first phase of 100 trees on the way later this year, coinciding with Armistice Day and the centenary of the end of the First World War.
The project, which represents the largest single planting of heavy standard trees the council has ever undertaken, includes the creation of long, leafy avenues at five parks - Firth Park, Longley, Greenhill, Herdings and the Cholera Monument grounds. A single English oak will be positioned at 31 locations…
Special dedication ceremonies are happening and it is hoped THE FULL COMPLEMENT OF 300 TREES WILL BE IN PLACE BY 2020.
[…]
The measure follows a controversial decision in December by the council to fell and replace 41 memorial trees as part of its Streets Ahead roadworks programme with contractor Amey. Twenty-three of those to be felled were on Western Road, Crookes, and remembered local school pupils who lost their lives from 1914 to 1918.”
Source:
https://www.thestar.co.uk/news/growing-c...
https://web.archive.org/web/202008162325...
At the Sheffield City Council (SCC) ‘Tree Fayre’, at the SCC Botanical Garden, on Saturday 20th May 2023, the SCC Community Forestry Manager - LEONIE KAPADIA – informed that she has a spreadsheet that details the site location and on-site location of each of the 300 ‘heavy standard*’ World War 1 memorial trees that were planted in fulfilment of the Council resolutions of 13/12/2017. At the Fayre, Ms Kapadia informed that she is willing to share the aforementioned spreadsheet with the general public, upon request. Requests were made to Ms Kapadia on 20/5/2023; 12/6/2023 & 27/6/2023. However, Ms Kapadia neglected to respond to all requests.
SOURCE:
Professor Ian Rotherham’s blog; comment 7057 - ‘WW1 MEMORIAL TREES UPDATE – 20/5/2023’ (transcript and audio file):
https://ianswalkonthewildside.wordpress....
https://web.archive.org/web/202306072319...
Please note that, in response to the recently published ‘SHEFFIELD STREET TREES INQUIRY REPORT’, SCC has reiterated the commitment it made in February 2016: to being “OPEN AND TRANSPARENT WITH THE SHEFFIELD PUBLIC ENSURING ALL RELEVANT INFORMATION IS AVAILABLE IN THE PUBLIC DOMAIN”.
See the following:
1)
SCC minutes from the meeting of full Council that was held on the 3rd of February 2016:
http://democracy.sheffield.gov.uk/docume...
https://web.archive.org/web/201912030152...
2)
SCC minutes from the “extraordinary meeting” - Wednesday, 10th May 2023:
https://democracy.sheffield.gov.uk/docum...
https://web.archive.org/web/202307032226...
REQUEST 1:
Please provide a complete, unredacted copy of that spreadsheet.
REQUEST 2:
Please provide the most accurate ordnance survey grid coordinates that SCC has for the position of each of the 300 war memorial trees planted in fulfilment of the SCC Cabinet resolution made on 13/12/2017.
REQUEST 3:
Please provide a site plan for each planting site, showing the planting position of each of the WW1 memorial trees planted and currently growing, relative to other site features.
Ms Kapadia also implied that SCC no longer intends to honour its commitment to ‘replant’ (restock) “IN PERPETUITY” whenever one of the 300 war memorial trees has died, or is uprooted or destroyed.
REQUEST 4:
On 13/12/2017, when SCC committed to plant 300 war memorial trees, it also committed to ‘replant’ (restock) those ‘in perpetuity’, as well as all war memorial trees on highways. Has that commitment to replant ‘in perpetuity’ been revoked? If so, please provide all written SCC communications - formal and informal (from SCC Officers – including executives – and SCC politicians) - that represent a record this decision.
* For the definition ‘heavy standard’ - trees with a minimum height of 3.5m - see British Standard 3936 part 1:
https://web.archive.org/web/202008111203...
NOTE:
WHEN RESPONDING TO THIS FOI REQUEST, PLEASE DO NOT REPOST THE FOI REQUEST AS PART OF YOUR RESPONSE; JUST POST YOUR RESPONSE. DITTO FOR ALL SUBSEQUENT ASSOCIATED SCC COMMUNICATIONS ON WHATDOTHEYKNOW
Yours faithfully,
Mr Long

Dear Mr Long,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Memorial Trees
which we received on 04/07/2023.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
Our commitment was to plant 300 war memorial trees.
• Phase 1 was completed in November 2018 when 102 heavy standard trees
were planted as individual specimens or as part of avenues in 37
different parks locations.
• Phase 2 was completed in November 2019 when a further 12 heavy
standard trees were planted, one as an individual specimen and 11 to
extend the avenue at Longley Park
• Phase 3 was completed in February 2020 when 200 feathered trees and
whips were planted to create a wet woodland copse at Manor Playing
Fields (Pipworth Rec).
In total 314 trees were planted to satisfy the commitment.
Please find attached the record of locations, species and grid reference
co-ordinates of each tree/planting.
The has been no revocation of our commitment to ‘maintain in perpetuity’
these trees.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[2]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear Mr Long,
Internal Review of Environmental Information Regulations Request –
Reference – EIR-885887
Thank you for your email requesting a review of Sheffield City Council’s
response to your Environmental Information Regulations request. We
endeavour to provide a response to internal reviews within 40 working
days. However, a review can sometimes be delayed and I apologise for this.
I can now confirm that a full and impartial review of the decision made in
this case has been conducted with a summary as follows:
You contacted the Council on 4^th July 2023, requesting information
relating to memorial trees. The Council responded on the 1^st August 2023.
included map hyperlinks that were inactive.
Your email received by the Council on 5^th August 2023 explained that you
were requesting an internal review of the above response as the response
did not provide the information requested.
I have reviewed the details of your complaint and have determined that the
position outlined in the original response provided should be not be
upheld. A file is attached with the locations of the trees.
For your information when reviewing the maps, in the majority of the maps
the WW1 memorial tree is the one that is highlighted. Where this isn’t the
case it has been made clear in title of the map. This usually occurs when
there is an avenue of trees and one of them isn’t a WW1 memorial.
The 200 feathers and whips are shown in a polygon. The map says there are
2100 trees in the polygon of which 200 are the memorial trees. The Council
is unable to provide the exact location of these 200 trees within the
wider group of 2100 trees.
If you are dissatisfied with my review, you can make a complaint to the
Information Commissioner’s Office: [1][
email address
]
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear SCC FOI Officer,
Thank you for providing the spreadsheet. However, it would appear that the information provided in column G should be split between three different columns.
1)
Please provide a column heading for column G, to clarify what information is provided in the column, to aid understanding.
2)
Some of the information provided in column G of the spreadsheet is wrong. It would appear that the information has been shuffled so that coordinates (grid references) for one site have been wrongly associated with another. This has happened for trees at several sites (possibly many/most). For example, see the ordnance survey grid references provided for Endcliffe Park, Hillsborough Park, 'Middlewood Park' and 'Oughtibridge Park'.
3)
In your response, please confirm whether or not a SCC Officer has checked that all of the information provided in column G of the spreadsheet is correct, since my submission of this communication (dated 25/1/2024).
Please check the information provided in Column G, correct the errors - there will be many more, no doubt - and provide the correct ordnance survey grid coordinates that SCC has for the position of each of the 300 war memorial trees that were planted in fulfilment of the SCC Cabinet resolution made on 13/12/2017. This is to provide the information requested in item 2 of my original request, dated the 4th of JULY 2023:

Mr Long
